Johns Hopkins University
President Dr. Steven Muller has
been named U.S. Ambassador to
France, President James E. Carter
announced this morning. He will
replace retiring envoy Arthur A.
Hartman on January 31st.
The President said in a White
House statement to be released
later this morning, "Dr. Muller is
the embodiment of a
representative of this country. In
my work with him on the White
House Fellows committee, the
Council of Foreign Relations and
more recently on the World
Hunger Commission, I have come
to admire Dr. Muller's refined
personal style, his honesty, hard
work and drive, his even
temperament, his feel for the
subtleties of diplomacy, his love
for his fellow man and his terrific
tan. The American Ambassador
to France faces many political
challenges in this ever more
interdependent and uncertain
world of today. I'm confident
that Steve Muller will
triumphantly meet these
challenges."
Dr. Muller would not confirm
the appointment, but did say,
"All American diplomats face
some of the most vexing
challenges of any professional
today, and I anticipate many

such exciting challenges in the
years ahead. My time at Hopkins
has not been easy, but it has been
highly fulfilling. The problems of
today are by no means solved,
and as new challenges arise, it
will indeed be difficult to bring
the ship to superior station.
While I will be away from
Hopkins, I will naturally miss
those who I have come to admire
and respect, and I never want to
see again the people here whom I
despise and disdain."
Dr. Muller's appointment came
in the aftermath of a
behind-the-scenes campaign to
gain the attention of the
Administration and the French
government. Last February, Dr.
Muller hosted a speech by the
chief foreign affairs aide to
French President Valery Giscard
d'Estaing. On Commemoration
Day last spring, Dr. Muller and

the French Ambassador to the
United States heard a speech by
well-known French intellectual
and anthropologist, Claude
Levi-Strauss, the father of
structuralism.

So Long Steve

President Muller's appointment as U.S. ambassador to
France is a tremendous credit to the University. Only now
as he leaves can we begin to appreciate how fortunate we
have been to possess such a talented man for the leader of
our institution.
It is true that the University faces a difficult and
uncertain future in the wake of his departure. It will take a
man of great drive and determination to duplicate the
sceminly 'impossible feats of our departing President. He
will have to be capable of simultaneously building the
University into a renowned liberal arts institution while
substantially reducing the faculty in these same
departments. He will have to be able to launch a bold new
drive to start a new School of Engineering while at the same
time cutting administrative costs and personnel. He will
have to be able to institute a $400,000 core curriculum
project to prevent premature undergraduate specialization
when the University is also starting to offer a six-year PhD
program for 18-year-olds.
In truth, President Muller has done an incredible job. His
talents will ensure his success in his new role as a top
American diplomat. We will miss him very badly here at
Hopkins as he continues his brilliant career.

We Must Type
The recently instituted core curriculum program has so
far produced a few pomising course proposals. But one
offering which could be of considerable benefit to a large
number of undergraduates has been completely neglected.
The quality of written materials produced by students is
atrocious. Any so-called educated person graduating from
Hopkins should be able to type competently.
Typing should be instituted as a regular credity offering
at Hopkins. In fact, we feel it should be made a required
course for all undergraduates, no matter what their major.
What good is it if somebody can recite all 120 odd
Shadespearean sonnets from memory or diagram the nearon
structure of a Japanese tree frog if he can't put it on paper
in a reasonable manner. The 20th century has seen
incredible technological advances. A person who can't type
is simply not equipped to function in the modern world.
Not only would typing as a credity offering satisfy this
basic educational goal, it would also provide a useful.
practical benefit for many Hopkins studctns. How often has
someone -stayed up all night pecking away on an
assignment, when with any rudimentary knowledge of
typing he coold have finished in half the time? And the
supposedly "neat" handwriting submitted inlieu of typed
pages has caused terminal eyestrain in many an editor.
of course, people are inevitabely going to complain that
typing is not dignified cnoughto be taught in such a great
and prestigious university. But isn't it true that Hopkins
students regularly receive three credits fof looking at dirty
pictures under the auspices of Dr. Money in his sex course?
If that can be taught here, so can typing.
Others might say such a course would be too easy, not
challenging enough for Hopkins students. There are many
departments where it would blend in quite well, however.
Allow us to suggest the Writing Seminars as one logical
possibility.
